Approximately 2.5 cm of new snow over 30 cm of melt forms over 100 cm of old wind slabs over 15 cm depth hoar. Most of the snowpack is composed of rounded grains or facets becoming rounded. Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was a full test plus pit dug for the students on the Avi forecasting class. Good snow pack.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Experienced 3-4 good collapses today, presumably on that layer of buried surface hoar that was discovered to be approximately 60cms below the snow surface.

-All stability tests were done with a snow surface height of 142cm -All Failures occurred in the 95-113cm Layer or at the ground surface -Density, SWE, Crystal Size and Temp Profile were not recorded for this pit -All stability tests resulted in Q3 Shear Quality, except the 1st ST which resulted in Q2

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Approx 20 hits before depth hoar began to sluff away below shovel. After digging pit, we traversed skier's right approx 50 feet and experienced a collapse and cracking of the new snow slab sitting on top of a buried surface hoar layer. No surface hoar noted in the pit we dug at this exact location. We observed ECTP 11 and ECTP 6 on the buried surface hoar layer at the location of the collapse and cracking. We descended down the ridge to the lower angle terrain skier's right of the burn area.

Pit dug in a Ski Area; Poor pit location
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Below freezing temps on this shaded N aspect. A shovel tilt test identified a weak layer at 10m down. Surface hoar was widespread in this area.

We toured along a ridge in Middle Basin at Beehive. The N-NW winds were building cornices and wind deposition on leeward slopes. We observed shooting cracks on a low angle, wind loaded, East aspect. We determined the slope angle was not steep enough to cause slide in these conditions. Overall the layer of depth hoar seemed to be stabilizing as well as the snowpack as a whole. Due to high winds observed on ridge lines and moderate winds experienced on our tour we believe the avalanche danger to be moderate.

We toured along a ridge in Middle Basin at Beehive. The N-NW winds were building cornices and wind deposition on leeward slopes. We observed shooting cracks on a low angle, wind loaded, East aspect. We determined the slope angle was not steep enough to cause slide in these conditions. Overall the layer of depth hoar seemed to be stabilizing as well as the snowpack as a whole. The sun crust at the top of the snowpack might cause problems in future. Due to high winds observed on ridge lines and moderate winds experienced on our tour we believe the avalanche danger to be moderate.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Triggered by second skier who was caught but not buried or injured. Snowpack on this west side of the ridge was remarkably weaker and faceted below 90 cm compared to the east side. Not really an issue b/c the surface hoar layer is the weakest layer and the main problem. We had only one very small collapse the entire time we were out. I thought there would be more.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Surface hoar stripe was very obvious. If there were no surface hoar, this would be a stable snowpack and the only problem would be upside down storm snow which is hardly a problem at this point.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Skier triggered slide. We did not experience any collapsing but the party who triggered this slide experienced some collapsing while skinning up through low elevation terrain. The avalanche broke on surface hoar at 79 cm.
Previous wind loading noted on westerly and easterly aspects.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: CT test was performed on the leftover ECT column. The layer at 190 was a 3-5cm sun crust. The layer at 119 was a combo of sun crust and explosive crust from early season control work. There was no evidence of shots thrown in this area in the snowpack above this layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: HS>370cm. No wind loading observed up to 12pm. Winds were slightly increasing at that point. No signs of instability observed.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Hard Crust @ 210cm from surface. Snowpack >400cm at this location. Rimed Plate layer appears to be starting to round.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent activity on different slopes; Instability rapidly rising; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit located on S-facing slope of Mt Gordon Lyon, 0.25 mi NW of S. frk Eagle River saddle. Wind loading at time. Got ECTP12@27cmQ3 on rounding facet layer. whumping on similar slopes.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Did not dig to ground.

Upper layers of snowpack were upside down and very obvious on foot and on sleds. The small facets were found in another pit on similar aspect and elevation and produced ECTP25. There seems to be a slight crust under them and this layer is an obvious stripe in the snowpit wall. It looked like there were a few surface hoar crystals as well but these were very hard to find.
Video of pit: https://youtu.be/klRb0-6BL9g Photo of pit: http://www.mtavalanche.com/images/17/digging-snowpit-s-madison-range

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent activity on similar slopes
We skied slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ruggigt väder, dålig sikt, snö i luften och snöblint.

When pulling column with shovel from behind, the column broke at 51cm and 74 cm. Facets was not observed in associated MFcr layers, but hardness (P-) suggests that bindings in the 50 cm MFcr layer has been more weakened than in the layer at 74 cm. Thus, I consider the layer at 50-44 cm to be the weakest layer.

Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Var i lä. Tidigare mätning på exponerad plats visade 18 m/s. Sluttningen i stort var i ostlig riktning. Gropen var i en mindre ravin.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Fewer layers seen in this pit compared to lower elevations in Silver Fork. Weakest snow is the new snow of large, fragile stellars. When we got above treeline in an area with just a little wind, the new snow sluffed very easy and ran far distances. More snow and more wind overnight will mean more dry loose avalanches and sensitive wind slabs.
Weak snowpack, however the lack of slab in the snowpack promote good stability.

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No data below 110 cm
Did not observe below 110cm

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dålig sikt med starkt drev längs kalfjället. Profilen tagen i en läsluttning, liten sänka, från senaste 48h vind, NV. HS är >240cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: General profile: in some areas, either a thin mf crust or thin wind crust separates the surface facets from the few inches of low density snow.

Some Surface Hoar found at 160 cm but very hard to find. We dug another pit on a NW aspect at 7900 ft and found nearly identical stratigrahpy and test results. The only difference was that there were no ice crusts. Facets under the ice crust at 160 cm have no load. The weakest snow at the moment are the fragile stellar crystals in the new snow. Some stellars are 6mm in size. Some are rimed.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Recent activity on similar slopes
We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: New snow slab (from 180 down to 162) on top is layer of concern, not heavy right now, but could become more problematic as it settles or receives additional loading. Currently the SWE is 11% in this layer. Areas of concern are greater in windloaded open areas.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Clouds quickly moved in from the south. Winds increased out of the SW and were strong enough to move surface snow around. Temperatures remained cool. Snow started to fall around 3:00 pm and precipitation intensity has increased ever since.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Sammen med Lasse Vanebo.
ETCP 212 som propagerte hadde score mellom 22-28.

Pit_Observation.activities: Instability rapidly rising
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowing very hard. Tracks blown in quickly. 25 to 40cm of new snow by 1500. East/South/West winds, gusty and variable. No recent avalanches but visibility was less than 1/4 mile and at times only a few hundred feet. Wind slabs primary concern, with drifts 60-80cm deep. Storm slab characteristics decent. Cornice formation continuing. Total HS: unknown, at least >300cm. Probe could not hit ground. Height of new snow at this time and location: 25 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Just above t-verse to Frenchman's south slopes
Buried surface hoar at 60 cm looks like it was knocked over before it was buried and this matches what I've seen in many other pits.

Relatively low elevation for this area. Main concern is what gets buried when the next snow comes. Slopes getting some sun have a crust with facets above and below and surface hoar on top. Direct south is getting baked, but E aspects may remain a problem. Also, little rain fell at this elevation and the last week of precip was mostly snow.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in large open are below treeline.

User.name: Brandon Schwartz
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very little change in snow depth since a week ago. A lot of precip fell as rain.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Thick ice layer at 80-89 cm is from mid December rain (Dec 16?). This avalanche broke just below this ice layer. The storm total was about 10 inches of SWE that caused this avalanche and the widespread avalanche cycle in the Wellsville Range. Below 60 cm it was brushy.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Below SOB Traverse, Warren Miller Meadows

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Level 1 Class - Group A

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack mostly facets. This slope had a wind slab that promoted propagation. Most slopes just weak, but no slab to make them unstable. Snowpack 500' higher was 110cm of mostly facets.
Overall snowpack stable. Layer of concern is between new snowfall and wind loaded layer. Stability tests showed that the layer is starting to bound as sheer characteristic is non-planer (with Q3).
